PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
A.  Justification 
 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will help prepare the detailed design of 
the SDP. A consulting firm will be required to design the SDP along with the implementation 
framework and is proposed to be hired under the PPTA using Quality and Cost-Based Selection 
with 80/20 quality to cost ratio. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm’s activities, outputs, 
deliverables, and terms of reference are given below:   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The TA consulting firm will prepare the following outputs: (i) an inception report outlining the 
overall implementation plan at end of the first month of consultant mobilization, with a detailed 
proposed methodology for assisting in preparing the design of the two components of the SDP, 
financial and economic analyses, a social and poverty survey and data collection requirements and 
schedule; (ii) an midterm report with a detailed assessment of the SDP components at the interim 
stage along with key policy reforms and specific project-related issues within the fourth month of 
consultant mobilization; the midterm report will include SDP due diligence reports, draft gender 
action plan (GAP), draft social action plan, draft procurement plan and capacity assessment, and 
draft financial management assessment; (iii) a draft final report with a detailed assessment of the 
technical, financial, economic, environmental, social, and institutional aspects within the fifth month 
of consultant mobilization; and (v) a final report within the sixth month of consultant mobilization. 
The reports will be provided in both English and Kyrgyz/Russian. The TA consulting firm will hold 
extensive  consultations  to  discuss  the  SDP  design,  performance,  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system, ADB’s safeguards policy, and disbursement and procurement policies and guidelines. 
Detailed outputs of the TA consulting firm will include: 
  
(i)   Sector and subsector analysis and technical review. The consultants will conduct a 
comprehensive  review  of  the  education  sector  in  Kyrgyz  Republic  using  primary  and 
secondary sources. To help finalize the SDP design elements, a technical review  will 
examine the technical design of all components to make sure they are technically sound, 
meet all relevant technical standards and safeguard requirements, and are suitable for ADB 
financing support. Based on the review, the consultants will recommend improvements to 
the technical design of each SDP component based on best national or international good 
practices. The review will focus on: 
  School Curriculum and Textbook Development Plan. Current state of implementation 
of curriculum development, including profiled as well as specialized curriculum will be 
reviewed. A draft plan will be prepared consistent with international good practice such 
as separation of development, review and endorsement, and printing of textbooks. 
  In- and pre-service teacher training assessment report. The assessment will review 
the existing scope and structure of the in-service and pre-service teacher training system 
and will provide recommendations for improvements. Concept and draft action plan of 
pedagogical education and training will be developed to provide, if possible, for a single, 
coherent system of education and training modules’ development.  
  Proposed  policy  reforms  and  legislation.  This  component  will  support 
institutionalization  of  reforms  by  drafting  relevant  regulations,  charters,  regulatory 
amendments to ensure an appropriate legal framework for the provision of high quality 
school education.  
  Teacher  training  accreditation  system  development  plan.  This  component  will 
provide the basis for development of a teacher training accreditation system for the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  that  is  in  conformity  with  the  Bologna  Process  requirements  and

2 
standards for operation of an accreditation council. The consultants will develop: (i) draft 
standards for teachers and the accreditation council, (ii) an accreditation manual for 
assessment of pedagogy programs; and, (iii) requirements for training of evaluators for 
assessment of programs.  
  MS program in pedagogy. An MS and eventually a doctoral program in pedagogy are 
planned to be implemented by the Kyrgyz Republic. This component will help develop: (i) 
a  consensus  among  key  stakeholders  on  the  parameters  of  the  MS  and  the  PhD 
program;  (ii)  institutional  requirements  for  offering  of  the  two  programs;  and  (iii) 
requirements for collaboration with international institutions to ensure high quality of the 
program.  
  Selection  methodology  of  innovative  schools.  To  clearly  define  the  concept  of 
innovative resource schools and propose a selection methodology that factors in existing 
resources, location, student and faculty size, and other relevant criteria. A minimum set 
of  improvements  will  also  be  proposed  including  access  to  general  facilities  (e.g. 
functional  sanitary  for  boys  and  girls/women),  and  additional  resources  such  as 
laboratory facilities, infrastructure, and improved teacher training.  
  Improved community participation in schools. With close consultation of all relevant 
stakeholders draft a legal framework for model parent-teacher association charter with 
close  teacher-parent  cooperation;  clear  structures  for  school  improvement  and 
management; and with identified funding and other incentives to stimulate community 
participation in schools.  
  Monitoring  and  Evaluation  System.  To  develop  proposals  for  monitoring  and 
evaluation systems to monitor and evaluate pace and progress of reforms under the 
SDP.  
(ii)   Design  and  monitoring  framework  (DMF).  The  consultants  will  discuss  and  reach 
preliminary agreement with the SDP executing and implementing agencies on (a) project 
impact,  outcome,  outputs,  components,  indicators,  data  sources  and  activities;  (b) 
preliminary project costs, implementation activities, and timeframes; and (c) problem-tree 
and objective-tree analyses, and DMF for the SDP as a whole. The SDP is classified as 
effective  gender  mainstreaming  and  the  consultants  will  identify  suitable  actions  and 
indicators from the GAP for incorporation into the DMF. 
(iii)   Project administration manual (PAM). The consultants will prepare the draft PAM as per 
ADB template including (a) information and schedules describing implementation including 
project readiness filters; (b) project implementation roles and responsibilities of EAs, IA and 
ADB;  (c)  implementation  arrangements  including  costs  and  financing,  financial 
management, consulting services and procurement, safeguards, performance monitoring, 
evaluation, and reporting and communications. The PAM will include a procurement plan to 
cover procurement of goods and services including civil works, equipment, furniture, and 
consulting services. PAM will be prepared through a consultative process with government 
and ADB and will be agreed initially at loan fact-finding.  
(iv)   Financial and economic analysis. The consultants will undertake financial and economic 
analysis to: (i) ensure that the SDP cost estimates, financing plan, and financial analyses 
meet ADB requirements and (ii) to determine least-cost and affordability analyses, where 
applicable, to ensure that the economic analysis meets ADB requirements. The consultants 
will then prepare the required linked documents. The financial management assessment of 
the EAs and IA, and an analysis of sector budgets and financing will also be done. 
(v)   Poverty, social and gender assessments. The consultants will engage with all relevant 
stakeholders  and  conduct  surveys  (where  required)  for  poverty,  social,  and  gender 
analyses in accordance with ADB guidelines and templates. This will include a stakeholder 
participation plan, a gender action plan (GAP), and summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy. The SDP is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. The GAP will aim to

3 
ensure maximum project benefits for girls and women. The consultants will prepare the 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy. 
 
(vi)   Risk assessment and management plan. The consultants will work with stakeholders to 
identify  potential  project-related  risks  and  prepare  draft  governance,  procurement  and 
corruption risk assessment and develop a risk mitigation plan. The consultants will also 
prepare the required linked document and appendices to the report and recommendations 
of the President.  
(vii)   Institutional reviews. Review institutional arrangements proposed for SDP implementation 
(e.g. a financial management assessment and a procurement assessment of the EA and IA 
and  the  project  implementation  unit)  to  assess  implementation  capacity  and  make 
recommendations for training and other measures to strengthen it as required.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement

disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

Cost-Based Selection (QCBS) will be employed in recruiting a firm using a simplified technical 
proposal. A total of 44.5 person-months will be needed of which 16.5 person-months will be 
international and 28 person-months national. The list of positions and the corresponding inputs in

Supplementary Appendix 7. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
7.  During the PPTA, a project management unit (PMU) will be established at the Ministry of 
Education and Science (EA). This will ensure that the SDP activities are already embedded in the 
administrative structure of the stakeholders. Extensive consultations will also be held with Ministry 
of Finance, the second EA for the program component.  
 
8.  The proposed TA is expected to be approved by 28 June 2013 and will run for 6 months 
from Sep 2013 to Mar 2014. The processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
